citations.narrative:
APHIS reviewed the facility’s records for "Kharabali", (a 9 year old female whale), which contained multiple entries
documenting injuries the animal sustained on the surfaces of the primary enclosures where she was housed. For
example, records note that on 26-Oct-2023, the rostrum was bleeding after contacting a corner, after which she bumped
into a pole. Records document that Kharabali 'bumped' the wall and/or pole 11 times on 08-Nov-2023, and had increased
respiratory rates, a possible indicator of pain and/or distress. Records note mandibular/maxillary osteomyelitis and a
possible hairline fracture on 14-Nov-2023. Facility records note that on 28-Nov-2023 Kharabali injured herself again, and
on 2-Dec-2023, she was diagnosed as having bilateral mandibular fractures. There are notations throughout the records
of placing buoys, pads, and staff in the habitat intermittently to protect her from hitting surfaces. In the records, on 3-Dec-
2023, it is noted that staff had been evacuated from water due to 'lighting', and Kharabali was noted to 'make contact' with
rostrum on wall multiple times ('5x-1x was hard') during this timeframe. Approximately one hour later, a buoy wall was
constructed and deployed from the skimmer box to the door at the surface level. Subsequently, the records show that on
8-Dec-2023 Kharabali hit the wall with her rostrum and sank to the bottom, and on 9-Dec-2023, the facility placed pool
noodles to prevent contact with the walls. These reactive measures were inadequate protection for this animal, based on
the progression of existing injuries, and continuing documentation of contact with the walls in the records. Handling of
animals must be done in a manner that does not cause trauma, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
Correct by 7-Feb-2024

Preliminary and final necropsy reports for "Kharabali", (a 9 year old female beluga whale), reported on 14-Dec-2023 and
30-Jan-2024, respectively, were reviewed by APHIS and other federal officials. Neither report described the oral lesions of
dental disease and maxillary/mandibular fractures as described in the pre-mortem records as an 'open fracture' on 08-
December-2023. The recorded reproductive ultrasounds performed for monitoring describes a prominent uterus on 27-
October-2023, and also 07-December-2023, but no description of an evaluation of the uterus was recorded in necropsy
records. A preliminary necropsy report must be prepared by the veterinarian listing all pathologic lesions observed.
Correct by 18-Mar-2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Tonya Hadjis, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist
Carolyn McKinnie, Senior Veterinary Medical Officer - Marine Mammals and Exotics n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
APHIS reviewed the facility’s records for "Kharabali", (a 9 year old female whale), which contained multiple entries 
documenting injuries the animal sustained on the surfaces of the primary enclosures where she was housed. For 
example, records note that on 26-Oct-2023, the rostrum was bleeding after contacting a corner, after which she bumped 
into a pole. Records document that Kharabali 'bumped' the wall and/or pole 11 times on 08-Nov-2023, and had increased 
respiratory rates, a possible indicator of pain and/or distress. Records note mandibular/maxillary osteomyelitis and a 
possible hairline fracture on 14-Nov-2023. Facility records note that on 28-Nov-2023 Kharabali injured herself again, and 
on 2-Dec-2023, she was diagnosed as having bilateral mandibular fractures. There are notations throughout the records 
of placing buoys, pads, and staff in the habitat intermittently to protect her from hitting surfaces. In the records, on 3-Dec-
2023, it is noted that staff had been evacuated from water due to 'lighting', and Kharabali was noted to 'make contact' with 
rostrum on wall multiple times ('5x-1x was hard') during this timeframe. Approximately one hour later, a buoy wall was 
constructed and deployed from the skimmer box to the door at the surface level. Subsequently, the records show that on 
8-Dec-2023 Kharabali hit the wall with her rostrum and sank to the bottom, and on 9-Dec-2023, the facility placed pool 
noodles to prevent contact with the walls. These reactive measures were inadequate protection for this animal, based on 
the progression of existing injuries, and continuing documentation of contact with the walls in the records. Handling of 
animals must be done in a manner that does not cause trauma, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. 
Correct by 7-Feb-2024 
3.110(g)(1) 
   
Veterinary care. 
Preliminary and final necropsy reports for "Kharabali", (a 9 year old female beluga whale), reported on 14-Dec-2023 and 
30-Jan-2024, respectively, were reviewed by APHIS and other federal officials. Neither report described the oral lesions of 
dental disease and maxillary/mandibular fractures as described in the pre-mortem records as an 'open fracture' on 08-
December-2023. The recorded reproductive ultrasounds performed for monitoring describes a prominent uterus on 27-
October-2023, and also 07-December-2023, but no description of an evaluation of the uterus was recorded in necropsy 
records. A preliminary necropsy report must be prepared by the veterinarian listing all pathologic lesions observed. 
Correct by 18-Mar-2024

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Tonya Hadjis, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist 
Carolyn McKinnie, Senior Veterinary Medical Officer - Marine Mammals and Exotics n
